At 11:35 AM 4/19/02 -0400, you wrote:
>Well it sounds like you are most definitely doing some sort of functional 
>testing, so I'll base my comments on that. If your issue is simply that 
>you want to guarantee the ordering of your test cases, you can cheat by 
>having white box knowledge of the implementation of junit. If you don't 
>use the reflection method of adding tests (i.e. - explicitly adding the 
>test) you know that the tests will execute in the same order in which they 
>were added. Note that JUnit does not advertise any contract in this area 
>and the underlying implementation of test case execution could change at 
>any release.

i am new to testing an junit, but it it seems that you would like the unit 
tests for each class to be run before any tests that involve combinations 
of a class or involve a package at a higher level. if you get a bunch of 
errors in your utility package, you probably want to bail and reporting 
these in a bottom up manner will make it easier to see where the problem 
starts.

>...
>Functional testing of API's have many of the same design and usage 
>patterns of any functional test tool out on the market. Keep in mind that 
>if tests have dependencies - you will effectively be blocked from 
>executing dependent tests when you encounter a failure. This has a bad 
>smell, weather you are doing functional, unit - or using a commercial tool 
>like Silk or LoadRunner. That being said, sometimes it does make sense to 
>couple test cases, or a series of test cases - but you need to understand 
>the tradeoffs before doing this.

i agree about the bad smell, but i am looking at using junit, cactus, 
httpunit etc. to test some web apps. it seems that there are at least 3 
levels of tests from unit tests on each class to a functional test of a web 
app. and the associated dependencies. does anyon know how people have 
structured their tests in such cases?

thanks
